item.content:encoded:
I have recently transitioned into a new position as a Research Ecologist at the United States Geological Survey Fort Collins Science Center under a USGS Postdoctoral Fellowship. I’ve been at the center since 2007, and my new role will afford me the chance to continue working with colleagues while building new collaborations. My research will focus on the effect of multiple disturbances on the structure of sagebrush, montane forest and agricultural ecosystems. The research will help to frame broad questions related to ecosystem resilience, resistance, persistence and vulnerability with regard to climate change and related natural and anthropogenic disturbance. I will collaborate with USGS colleagues that are program-based scientists (Patrick Anderson, Wyoming Landscape Conservation Initiative; Mark Vandever, Conservation Reserve Program) and place-based scientists (Craig Allen, Ellis Margolis, Collin Haffey, Jemez Mountain Landscape).

Open science advocates have started to share their proposals for a number of really good reasons; one of which is to help others write better proposals (see Ethan White’s excellent post on the subject). I’ve benefited from that ideology so I’ve decided to share my proposal here. My proposed research plan is admittedly brief, but it is somewhat unique because I had to wrap several disparate projects together under one umbrella (i.e. scientific synthesis and collaboration using space based observations) to meet the needs of my science center. Hopefully this proposal provides some background and context for others that need to link disparate projects under one proposal.
